discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Steve discovers Split Lease not through marketing but through his friend Joyce, who frames it as 'a marketplace for multi-locals.' This is critical through a Prospect Theory lens: Steve's reference point at discovery is already anchored by his current painful status quo -- he has no permanent lease, is house-sitting in Boston, storing belongings with friends, and living out of a suitcase at his girlfriend's house. His reference point is a state of loss (no stable housing), which means Split Lease enters his awareness not as a speculative gain but as potential loss-reduction. Kahneman's work on reference points shows that people in a loss state are risk-seeking -- Steve is primed to take action. Additionally, the social proof from Joyce (a trusted, high-status friend and advisor) functions as what Kahneman calls 'anchoring through association': the platform inherits Joyce's credibility before Steve even sees it.

user_state.emotional: Motivated by pain of current situation (no lease, inefficient house-sitting, living out of suitcase). Curious and intellectually engaged -- Steve is analytical (Airtable data viz background) and enjoys discussing business models. Not desperate, but genuinely uncomfortable.
user_state.knowledge: High domain knowledge. Has done 6 months of digital nomadism, understands the multi-local concept viscerally. Knows Sonder as a competitor reference point. Has internalized the hotel-vs-home tradeoff from personal experience.
user_state.commitment: Low but warm. He is in an information-gathering mode, not actively searching for a solution. The call is a 'catch up' that happens to be relevant to his situation.
user_state.data: Steve mentions Sonder pricing ($90/night in Boston), his Airtable employment (remote-friendly), his lack of any lease, house-sitting for a friend, storing stuff with friends, girlfriend's small place.

discovery.dropout_risk: Medium. Steve is analytically sophisticated and will evaluate Split Lease against Sonder and other alternatives. If the platform does not immediately signal 'this is different from what you already know,' his System 1 will categorize it as 'another Airbnb variant' and disengage. The denominator neglect concept from Kahneman applies: Steve will focus on the vivid, easy-to-imagine features (price, photos) and may miss the structural advantage (medium-term, no tourist tax) unless it is made immediately salient.

key_quotes.quote: I always look month just to see like, oh, what did I miss? This, this is very relevant to my current situation.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Steve is scanning for loss-reduction. His reference point is his current unstable housing. Anything he discovers is evaluated as 'does this reduce my current losses?' not 'is this a nice gain?'

key_quotes.quote: Joyce was like, oh, so you're building a marketplace for multi-locals.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Joyce's framing creates an immediate reference point: 'marketplace for multi-locals' -- this is Steve's identity. The endowment effect begins here: Steve now mentally 'owns' the category label, making it harder for him to dismiss the platform.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Steve's search behavior is shaped by his analytical background and his existing reference points. He mentions Sonder explicitly ('I also say to Sonder quite a bit... in Boston, I can get it down to like 90 a month'). This is his price reference point. Kahneman's prospect theory shows that all subsequent pricing will be evaluated as gains or losses relative to this anchor. If Split Lease shows listings above $90/night without immediately explaining the structural difference (monthly rate, no cleaning fees, no tourist tax, leave your stuff), Steve will code the price as a loss relative to his Sonder reference. The certainty effect also applies: Sonder offers a known, certain experience. Split Lease offers an uncertain one (Who is the host? Will the space match photos? Can I trust a stranger's home?). The certainty premium means Steve requires Split Lease to be significantly cheaper or significantly better to overcome the certainty advantage of Sonder.

user_state.emotional: Calculating, comparative. Not browsing passively -- actively benchmarking against known alternatives (Sonder, hotels, friend's couch).
user_state.knowledge: Extremely high. Understands hotel pricing parity across cities, understands supply-demand dynamics, has personal experience with Airbnb/Sonder. Will scrutinize pricing more carefully than average guest.
user_state.commitment: Low. Search is exploratory. He has not committed to any platform or approach.
user_state.data: Sonder at $90/night in Boston as reference. Knows he doesn't need a kitchen (eats at girlfriend's house). Has no fixed schedule requirement.

search.dropout_risk: High. Steve is a sophisticated comparison shopper. If search results do not immediately surface the medium-term savings narrative and differentiate from Sonder/Airbnb, he will leave. The fourfold pattern from Kahneman suggests that in the 'high probability of moderate gain' quadrant (top left), Steve will be risk-averse -- he will prefer the sure thing (Sonder) over the uncertain thing (Split Lease) unless the expected value gap is made vivid and certain.

key_quotes.quote: I also say to Sonder quite a bit... in Boston, I can get it down to like 90 a month... I don't need a kitchen.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Sonder at $90/night is the reference price. Every Split Lease listing is now evaluated as gain or loss relative to $90. Steve's specific mention of 'I don't need a kitchen' reveals he is already making tradeoff calculations -- sacrificing kitchen access to reduce cost. Split Lease must show that he does NOT have to make this tradeoff.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: This is where the endowment effect and loss aversion collide. When Steve opens a specific listing, he begins to mentally 'try on' the space. Kahneman's endowment effect research shows that even brief mental ownership increases perceived value -- but it also increases the pain of discovering deal-breakers. For an analytical guest like Steve, listing evaluation is a two-system process: System 1 responds to photos and first impressions (does this feel like a place I could live?), while System 2 runs the financial math (nightly rate x nights x weeks = total cost vs Sonder). The critical insight from Prospect Theory is that Steve's evaluation of a listing is NOT about the absolute quality of the space. It is about gains and losses relative to his reference points: Sonder price, his friend's house in Boston (free but cramped), and the abstract ideal of having his own stable place. Any listing feature that falls below his reference point (smaller than expected, farther from transit, noisier neighborhood) is coded as a LOSS and weighted 2x more heavily than features that exceed his reference point.

user_state.emotional: Engaged but guarded. The analytical mind is running calculations. Emotional investment increases as photos create mental occupancy. Anxiety about whether this is 'real' or 'too good to be true' -- the rare events overweighting from Kahneman means Steve will overweight the small probability of scams or terrible host experiences.
user_state.knowledge: Deep. Steve understands the business model (he's been briefed on anchor/hot-deal matching, tax advantages, medium-term structure). But knowledge of the specific space and host is zero.
user_state.commitment: Medium-low. Mental ownership begins but is fragile. One bad signal (unclear photos, suspicious pricing, no host verification) triggers loss aversion and exit.
user_state.data: Steve evaluates: price relative to $90/night Sonder, distance to transit/work, whether he can store his belongings, host reliability signals.

listing_evaluation.dropout_risk: Very high. This is the phase where the most guests abandon. Kahneman's work on rare events shows that guests overweight dramatic negative outcomes (bad host, scam, arriving to find space unlike photos) even when the probability is very low. Steve explicitly mentions Sonder's text support being annoying (0:35:39) -- he notices operational friction. Any friction on the listing page (unclear rules, confusing pricing display, no host verification badge) will activate the same pattern.

key_quotes.quote: I rather like all my friends, like I have a thing in my room where I have a lot and then I'm house sitting for a friend of Boston, but it's just like very inefficient.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: The current arrangement is coded as a loss (inefficient). But it is a KNOWN loss. Status quo bias means Steve will tolerate this known loss rather than risk an unknown loss (bad Split Lease experience) unless the listing makes the gain vivid and certain.

key_quotes.quote: I lifted out of a suitcase at my girlfriend's house... she has a smaller place. She has a husband and I don't want to like stay in there for like a month.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Steve's status quo is actively painful. He is 'in the losses' as Kahneman describes the poor -- where all choices are between losses. This makes him more risk-seeking than a comfortable guest, which is an opportunity: he is more likely to try Split Lease than someone with stable housing.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Creating a proposal is the moment of maximal loss aversion activation. The guest must commit specific terms (dates, duration, price) and send them to a stranger. From a Prospect Theory perspective, this is a high-stakes gamble: the guest is risking rejection (a loss of time and emotional investment), risking overpaying (a financial loss), and risking the uncertainty of whether the host will be reasonable. The endowment effect works in reverse here: Steve does not yet 'own' the space, so the pain of potentially losing access to it is lower. But the mental investment of configuring a proposal -- choosing dates, calculating total cost, imagining himself in the space -- creates psychological ownership. Once he has configured the proposal, he has mentally moved in. Not sending it now feels like a loss (loss of the envisioned future). The certainty effect is paramount: Steve needs to know EXACTLY what happens after he submits. If there is ambiguity about the process (Will the host respond? How long will it take? What if they counter?), the uncertainty creates a certainty deficit that his System 1 will code as risk.

user_state.emotional: Tense. The commitment threshold is approaching. Fear of rejection and fear of bad outcome compete with desire for the space. Steve's analytical nature means he will want to understand every term before committing.
user_state.knowledge: Must be high by this point. If Steve does not understand anchor vs hot-deal matching, lease style implications, or cancellation policies, he will not submit.
user_state.commitment: Medium-high. He has invested time evaluating. The sunk cost is real (Kahneman notes people overvalue sunk costs). But the proposal is not yet sent.
user_state.data: Steve needs: exact total cost for his planned duration, comparison to Sonder monthly cost, cancellation terms, what happens if host counters.

proposal_creation.dropout_risk: High. The proposal creation form is where analytical guests like Steve encounter the full complexity of the platform. If the pricing display does not match his mental model (he thinks in monthly costs, not nightly rates), the translation burden triggers depletion. Kahneman's bat-and-ball problem: if the form shows $80/night and Steve's System 1 calculates '$80 x 30 = $2,400/month -- that's way more than Sonder,' he will leave without realizing the actual monthly cost is lower due to the part-time structure.

key_quotes.quote: Parody among hotel markets... hotels are offering roughly $170 a night in San Francisco and $170 a night in Chicago. But the average monthly rental rates between those two places are night and day.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Steve already understands the resegmentation math -- but he learned it through conversation with Igor, not from a platform interface. The proposal creation screen must replicate this insight visually: show the hotel reference price, then the Split Lease price, framing the difference as a gain.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: Negotiation is where Kahneman's work on concessions and loss aversion in bargaining applies directly. 'The concessions you make to me are my gains, but they are your losses; they cause you much more pain than they give me pleasure.' If the host counters Steve's proposal (e.g., reducing duration from 16 to 10 weeks as in the journey map), Steve will code this as a loss from his proposed terms -- even though the counter may be perfectly reasonable. The reference point has shifted: Steve's proposal is now his reference, and any deviation is a loss. The dual entitlements principle applies: Steve feels entitled to his proposed terms, and the host feels entitled to their own. The platform must frame counter-offers not as losses ('Your duration was reduced') but as gains from a neutral reference ('The host has offered you 10 weeks at the same nightly rate'). Steve's analytical background means he may be more rational about this than average, but his System 1 will still register the initial loss signal before System 2 overrides it.

user_state.emotional: Vulnerable. A counter-offer triggers loss aversion (my proposed terms were rejected). Even a reasonable counter feels like a setback. Steve's ego as an analytical thinker means he may have calibrated his proposal carefully and will feel the counter implies his judgment was wrong.
user_state.knowledge: Must understand that negotiation is normal and expected, not a sign of failure.
user_state.commitment: High but fragile. Steve has invested significantly. But the endowment effect now works against the platform: Steve is 'endowed' with his original proposal terms and will resist changes.
user_state.data: Steve needs: clear display of what changed, what stayed the same, and the total financial impact of the changes.

negotiation.dropout_risk: Medium-high. Kahneman's research on defending the status quo applies: 'Loss aversion creates an asymmetry that makes agreements difficult to reach.' If the counter-offer display emphasizes what was lost (shorter duration, different dates) rather than what was preserved or gained, Steve will feel the negotiation is adversarial and may abandon.

key_quotes.quote: One of the things that multi locals have is schedule uncertainty. They have a sense of schedule certainty in a sense of schedule uncertainty.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Igor identifies schedule uncertainty as the core tension. In negotiation, a counter-offer that changes dates activates uncertainty, which Steve's System 1 codes as a threat. The platform must provide certainty signals throughout negotiation -- confirmed dates should be visually locked and immovable.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: Acceptance is where the certainty effect reaches maximum power. Kahneman shows that moving from 95% to 100% certainty is psychologically massive -- far more impactful than moving from 50% to 55%. The moment of acceptance transforms a probable outcome into a certain one. This is the platform's single most powerful emotional moment. But Kahneman also warns about the endowment effect kicking in immediately: the instant Steve accepts, he mentally owns the space. From this point forward, any problem (delayed documents, unclear move-in instructions, unexpected fees) is coded as a loss from his newly established reference point of 'I have a place.' The platform must deliver flawlessly from this moment because any disappointment is amplified by loss aversion.

user_state.emotional: Relief and elation. The certainty of having a place after months of instability is profoundly positive. But this relief immediately creates a new, higher reference point that makes any subsequent disappointment feel worse.
user_state.knowledge: Must know exactly what happens next: when documents arrive, when payment is processed, when they can move in, who to contact.
user_state.commitment: Very high. The acceptance is a psychological point of no return.
user_state.data: Steve needs: confirmation of all agreed terms, timeline for next steps, contact information for host, payment schedule.

acceptance.dropout_risk: Low for abandonment, but HIGH for disappointment-driven negative reviews if the post-acceptance experience has any friction. Kahneman's loss aversion ratio (2:1) means that one bad post-acceptance experience (late documents, confusing payment) erases the positive effect of two good experiences.

key_quotes.quote: You can just have a satellite home and then have a permanent address. And your satellite home doesn't have to cost that much.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: The acceptance moment is when 'satellite home' moves from concept to reality. The endowment effect starts here. Steve now OWNS this concept -- taking it away (through friction, confusion, or delay) will feel like theft.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: Move-in is the first moment of reality testing against the reference point established at acceptance. Kahneman's research on the endowment effect shows that once Steve has mentally owned the space (from acceptance onward), his reference point includes every positive detail he imagined. The actual space is evaluated against this imagined version. Any discrepancy -- even minor ones (slightly different furniture arrangement, neighborhood noise, unclear parking) -- is coded as a loss. This is amplified by what Steve has been living through: months of no permanent space, suitcase living, friend's couches. His relief reference is extremely high, making the move-in a moment of extraordinary emotional stakes. The rare events overweighting from Kahneman also applies: Steve will be hyper-alert to any sign that something is wrong (bad lock, stained mattress, unclear instructions) because his System 1 is scanning for threats in an unfamiliar environment.

user_state.emotional: Extremely heightened. Mix of excitement (finally having a space) and anxiety (is it going to be what I expected?). First impressions of the physical space will be dominated by System 1 and coded permanently.
user_state.knowledge: Needs comprehensive House Manual before arrival. Uncertainty about logistics (key handoff, parking, trash, wifi) amplifies threat detection.
user_state.commitment: Fully committed. But psychological vulnerability is at its peak.
user_state.data: Steve needs: exact check-in procedure, host contact for day-of questions, neighborhood guide, house rules, wi-fi password -- all before he arrives.

move_in.dropout_risk: Low (he has already committed), but VERY HIGH for negative sentiment formation. A bad move-in experience creates a loss-aversion reference that poisons the entire active lease period. The 5:1 Gottman ratio applies: the platform needs 5 positive move-in moments to compensate for 1 negative one.

key_quotes.quote: Every time you have to set it up, your ROI is like a couple of days, even if it's ROI of karma.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Steve is acutely aware of setup costs. The move-in phase IS the setup cost. If it is friction-filled, his ROI calculation turns negative immediately, and he will code the entire Split Lease experience as a loss relative to his other options (Sonder requires zero setup).

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The active lease phase is where status quo bias and the endowment effect work FOR the platform -- if the initial experience is good. Once Steve is settled, his reference point shifts to 'I have a stable space.' Now, losing the space (lease ending, host problems, date conflicts) is coded as a devastating loss, while the ongoing experience is coded as the neutral status quo. This creates natural retention. But Kahneman's work on goals as reference points adds a nuance: if Steve sets expectations for the active lease (e.g., 'I should be able to change dates easily,' 'The host should be responsive'), not meeting those goals feels like a loss even though the absolute situation is good. The Date Change Tool is critical here: Kahneman's cabdriver study shows that people with daily targets work harder on bad days and coast on good days. Analogously, Steve will be most frustrated with the platform when things go wrong (date change needed urgently) and least attentive when things are fine. The platform's active lease experience must be designed for the bad days, not the good ones.

user_state.emotional: Settled and stable -- unless a problem arises, in which case anxiety spikes disproportionately (loss aversion). The endowment effect means Steve values the space far more now than he did when evaluating it.
user_state.knowledge: Growing over time. Steve learns the host's patterns, the neighborhood, the platform's tools. Familiarity reduces threat detection.
user_state.commitment: Very high. The endowment effect and status quo bias create strong retention. Switching to another platform now feels like a loss.
user_state.data: Steve needs: payment transparency (no surprise charges -- these are coded as losses), easy date management, responsive host communication, cleaning photo process that is frictionless.

active_lease.dropout_risk: Low for abandonment during an active lease, but HIGH for non-renewal if negative experiences accumulate. Kahneman's 'bad is stronger than good' principle means that the platform must prevent negative experiences rather than trying to create exceptionally positive ones. One terrible date-change experience or one payment surprise can undo months of satisfactory stays.

key_quotes.quote: Schedule certainty and schedule uncertainty... things could change or they want to tack on nights where they want their space back.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: Active lease is the phase where schedule uncertainty is resolved (or not). Each resolved date change is a certainty effect moment (relief). Each unresolved date conflict is a loss-aversion trigger. The Date Change Tool must deliver certainty rapidly.

key_quotes.quote: A much more sustainable living arrangement, in terms both price and quality, than say piecing together a bunch of hotel tonight stays.
key_quotes.prospect_theory_note: The active lease is where 'sustainable' is tested against reality. If the experience IS sustainable (predictable, low-friction, stable), the endowment effect locks Steve in. If it is NOT sustainable (unexpected costs, difficult host, complex tools), each instance of unsustainability is coded as a loss against the promise.

cross_phase_patterns.description: Steve's reference point shifts at every phase transition, and each shift creates new loss-aversion dynamics. Discovery: reference = current painful status quo (no lease, suitcase living). Search: reference = Sonder at $90/night. Listing evaluation: reference = imagined version of the space. Proposal: reference = the terms Steve configures. Negotiation: reference = the original proposal. Acceptance: reference = the agreed terms. Move-in: reference = the imagined space. Active lease: reference = the initial experience. The platform must manage each reference point transition deliberately, or the natural loss aversion at each shift will create dropout moments.

evidence.detail: Kahneman demonstrates that reference points shift immediately upon acquisition (real or mental). The minimum selling price for a mug was 2x the maximum buying price. Each phase transition in the guest journey creates an analogous shift.
Steve mentions Sonder pricing as his benchmark -- this is an explicit reference point that will persist into search and listing evaluation.

cross_phase_patterns.description: Steve is unusually analytical (data visualization at Airtable, understands financial mathematics from Igor's explanation, thinks in ROI terms). Kahneman shows that the certainty effect is universal, but for analytical guests it takes a specific form: they demand numerical certainty (exact costs, exact timelines, exact processes) rather than emotional certainty (trust signals, host photos, reviews). The platform must provide both types of certainty, but for Steve's segment, numerical certainty is the binding constraint. If total cost is ambiguous, if the comparison to Sonder is not made explicit, if the refund policy is unclear -- Steve will pay the certainty premium and stay with Sonder.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'An improvement from 95% to 100% is a qualitative change that has a large impact -- the certainty effect.' For Steve, the qualitative change is: from 'probably cheaper than Sonder' to 'definitely cheaper than Sonder by exactly $X per month.' The first is merely probable. The second is certain. The psychological gap is enormous.

Steve describes his current arrangement as 'very inefficient' and catalogues specific pain points (storing stuff with friends, suitcase at girlfriend's house). He is quantifying his losses. He will also quantify potential gains -- and if the numbers are not crystal clear, his System 2 will default to the known quantity (Sonder).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Loss-State Risk Seeking Creates an Acquisition Window
cross_phase_patterns.description: Kahneman's fourfold pattern shows that people in the domain of losses are risk-seeking. Steve is currently 'in the losses' -- no permanent lease, inefficient housing, living out of a suitcase. This means he is MORE willing to try a novel platform (Split Lease) than a guest who has stable housing. This is a time-limited acquisition window: once Steve finds any stable arrangement (even a suboptimal one), his reference point resets and he becomes loss-averse again (reluctant to switch). The platform must convert Steve during his loss-state window, before he settles into a new status quo.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Many unfortunate human situations unfold in the top right cell. This is where people who face very bad options take desperate gambles.' Steve is not desperate, but he IS in a loss state -- all his options are suboptimal. This makes him more open to the 'gamble' of trying Split Lease.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Endowment Effect section: people who are poor
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'People who are poor think like traders... their problem is that all their choices are between losses.' Steve is not financially poor, but he is housing-poor. All his choices are between imperfect options (friend's couch, girlfriend's small place, Sonder at $90/night). This 'all-losses' frame makes him more receptive to novel solutions.

Steve: 'I'm going to like shut it down, like to consolidate all my stuff... I basically work at Airtable. So I have like, basically my belongings friends who are...' He is describing active loss management. He is currently a loss-state guest.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Sonder as the Vivid Alternative that Reduces Probability Sensitivity
cross_phase_patterns.description: Kahneman's research on vivid outcomes shows that when an alternative is vivid and concrete, people become less sensitive to probability differences. Sonder is Steve's vivid alternative: he has used it, knows the price, knows the experience. This means that even if Split Lease has objectively better odds of a good outcome (lower price, better space, leave-your-stuff advantage), the vividness of the Sonder experience will compress Steve's sensitivity to these probability differences. The platform must make its own value proposition equally vivid -- not through abstract claims ('save up to 40%') but through concrete, imageable scenarios ('Your space in Cambridge: 3 nights/week, $X/month, leave your Airtable setup on the desk').

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'A rich and vivid representation of the outcome, whether or not it is emotional, reduces the role of probability in the evaluation of an uncertain prospect.' Sonder provides a vivid, imageable experience. Split Lease listings must match this vividness or lose the comparison.

Steve: 'I don't need a kitchen. I was just like cooking dinner at girlfriend's house.' He has already imagined his Sonder workflow in vivid detail. Split Lease must offer an equally detailed alternative vision.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Endowment Effect as Retention Engine
cross_phase_patterns.description: Kahneman shows that the endowment effect increases with duration of ownership and with the degree to which a good is held 'for use' rather than 'for exchange.' A Split Lease space -- where the guest leaves their belongings, sets up their workspace, learns the neighborhood -- is the ultimate 'for use' good. The endowment effect will be very strong after even a few weeks of active lease. This means retention during the active lease is nearly automatic IF the initial experience is good. But it also means that the loss of the space (lease ending, host withdrawing, forced move) will be experienced as devastating. The platform must manage lease-end transitions with extreme care, ideally offering renewal or transfer options that prevent the loss-coding entirely.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Selling goods that one would normally use activates regions of the brain that are associated with disgust and pain.' A Split Lease space is used, not traded. The endowment effect will be maximal. The loss aversion ratio may exceed the typical 2:1 for spaces where guests have left personal belongings.

Steve: 'For that six months I missed the house. Like I have to have them here.' He explicitly describes the endowment effect for a living space -- he missed his space during digital nomadism. Once he has a Split Lease space, the same attachment will form.
